ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: n/a
Honed in my lab skills and practiced speaking and presenting my data publicly

My senior project gave me the experience of having my own research project in a wet-lab. My lab challenged me a lot and expected me to perform on par with the grad students, which made me grow greatly as a scientist.
I was able to develop my abilities to problem-solve and manage my time as a more independent researcher. I also learned to write an extended piece and design a poster for scientific publication.
How to perform biotechnological skills in lab.
I gained extensive experience with designing original scientific research projects and pursuing investigations of relevant questions in my field of interest, immunology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: n/a
Adapted well to virtual presentations and the poster session was well-organized on Gather Town. At times, it was unclear on how exactly we were being graded

The course allowed me to spend a lot of time developing research skills and pursuing a certain research project. Often the assignments were not clearly discussed besides what was given in the syllabus, which made it difficult to know what the professors expected from me. I wish they had given us more information about expectations further in advance. I also think that the course professors should have "shown up" a little bit more for presentations and feedback because I often turned in work just to have it be left in the "void", with no comments or feedback. For example, the poster session required a lot of work but I had no visitors come, which was disappointing and felt disrespectful of the students' time.

20 hours is a lot, but you can get a lot done in the lab. COVID kinda screwed that over and it can be a lot esp during your senior year. Not sure how it could be improved. Strengths is that if you dedicate the time, you will see the results.

Weaknesses are the way they evaluate you. Seems like a lot of unnecessary things that they ask you to do, but ig that's life.

It's very dependent on your own lab environment, which could be good or bad. For me I had a very supportive mentor network in my lab, so getting credit to spend time I would have already spent in the lab was a plus. Otherwise, the instructors were more hands-off, which was helpful at the start of the semester, but a little more guidance toward the end of the semester (with clearer instructions) would have been helpful.
This course was quite self-directed, which enabled me to pursue my research in the way I saw best by coordinating more closely with my lab mentors and thesis advisor.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: n/a

Generally, things were pretty "normal" in terms of being able to work in person in my lab. I would say that the course organizers did a pretty poor job of explaining what assignments and presentations would look like in the remote setting. The course organizers also seemed pretty disengaged and barely gave any feedback after giving us a first semester presentation grade, which seemed arbitrary.
The poster symposium at the end of the year was held online. Also, options for bioinformatics-based labwork were made available.
There was very good de-densification done by West Campus / the Isaacs Lab which enabled my in-person research.

The online presentation format was highly effective and allowed us to present without safety concerns relating to COVID-19.  The end of year virtual presentation format was fun and unique, in retrospect.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes for the intensive major it is necessary
Yes, this was a great way to do senior research and get credit for it.
Yes if they are willing to commit the time, effort, and energy into working intensively in a lab during their senior year.
Only do if you are dedicated. Senior year is precious, but i figured that if I wanted to get good work done in the lab i needed to spend at least 20 hours per week.
Yes -- if you enjoy research, and/or if you were going to be working close to 20 hours in the lab anyway, then I recommend declaring an intensive major.
Yes. Good way to get your senior requirement done especially if you already are in lab a lot.

I would recommend this course over the non-intensive alternative if a student has a track record of spending more than 10 hours per week in lab. I felt that since it was quite typical to spend this amount of time in lab, the 20 hour-a-week requirement would likely be met regardless of my BS-intesnvie status. Given the length of this research project, the longer requirements for the final paper actually made things easier not harder.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Virtual Zoom presentation in the fall and virtual poster session in the spring
Virtual poster session at the end of the semester
This was a research course for the senior requirement. I learned through hands-on research performed in the Isaacs Lab.
Virtual Presentation Events.
